The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
Community College Chancellor’s Office (CCCCO) has allocated $25 million for two-year planning and implementation grants with the purpose of developing regional plans to better serve the educational needs of adults. Assembly Bill 86 (AB 86) outlines expectations for consortium development as well as planning and implementation requirements to establish the Adult Education Consortium Program. The central intent of AB 86 is to expand and improve the provision of adult education, via these consortia, with incremental investments starting with the 2015-16 fiscal year.
	 
Of that $25 million, $657,493 has been awarded to South Bay Consortium for Adult Education (SBCAE) that consists of the following member institutions:
San Jose-Evergreen Community College District (San Jose City College, Evergreen Valley College)
West Valley-Mission Community College District (West Valley College, Mission College)
San Jose Unified School District (Silicon Valley Adult Education)
Milpitas Unified School District (Milpitas Adult Education, including Santa Clara County Correctional Facilities)
East Side Union High School District (East Side Adult Education)
Campbell Union High School District (Campbell Adult and Community Education)
Santa Clara Unified School District (Santa Clara Adult Education)
	 
SBCAE covers the geographical boundaries of both the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District (SJECCD) and West Valley Mission Community College District (WVMCCD).  
	 
The grant awards being submitted for Board approval were determined by the state using a formula incorporating an equal base amount for each consortium to be used for core planning activities and two additional variables:
an amount based on the regional population (using census data)
an amount based on regional need as it relates to the planning areas defined by AB86 (using census data)
	 
SJECCD’s portion of the award is $392,202 and WVMCCD portion of the award is $265,291.  The total award for the SBCAE is $657,493.  The SBCAE has elected SJECCD to serve as its fiscal agent.  
	 
To prepare adult learners for college, career, and civic responsibility, the SBCAE will use the funds awarded to draft a plan that addresses the following areas by 2015:
Elementary and secondary basic skills, including classes required for a high school diploma or high school equivalency certificate
Classes and courses for immigrants eligible for education services in citizenship and English as a second language and workforce preparation classes in basic skills
Education programs for adults with disabilities
Short-term career technical education programs with high employment potential
Programs for apprentices 
	 
By 2015-16,  the SJECCD and its network educational institutions will offer:
Credit, enhanced credit, and non-credit programs and courses for adults
Seamless educational pathways for students to earn college certificates and degrees and/or prepare for workforce
Accelerated educational and/or workforce preparation programs for those who are balancing work, family, and other responsibilities
Workforce programs leading to employment opportunities that support the local economy
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the acceptance of grant funds in the amount of $$657,493 awarded to the South Bay Consortium for Adult Education, for which SJECCD is fiscal agent.

The San Jose Evergreen Community College District is a member of the South Bay Regional Public Safety Training Consortium (SBRPSTC) Joint Powers Authority (JPA).  The purpose of the SBRPSTC is to provide training and educational programs that are responsive to the needs of regional public safety agencies.  The SBRPSTC is governed by a Board of Directors.  The Board of Directors consist of one representative from each member community college district who are appointed by the Governing Board of the member college district.
	 
Currently the President of Evergreen Valley College represents the District; however, the President has requested that this representation be transferred to the Director of Fiscal Services.

On October 10, 2013 the Board approved a Contract to Bellinger Foster Steinmetz Landscape Architects for design, construction administration, and Division of the State Architect (DSA) coordination of the Central Green Project.  The project involves a renovation of existing pedestrian accessibility routes, hardscape, softscape, trees/plants/soil, irrigation, exterior wayfinding signage, and exterior lighting.  
	 
As the design and construction estimates for the Central Green Project have become more finalized, it has been determined that sufficient budget is available to include other items listed as priorities in the Campus Master Planning document.  Revision #001 includes design, construction administration and DSA coordination for the following added scopes of work:  1) An Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) compliant path of travel between the Gullo-1 and Central Plant buildings.  2) Replacement of the large exterior stairway between the Student Services and A&R buildings.  3) Addition of a structural enclosure to the electrical switchgear located at the Arts Plaza.  4) Addition of a design allowance to cover unforeseen conditions which may arise as a result of the additional scope in this Revision.     
	 
Bellinger Foster Steinmetz Landscape Architects submitted written pricing proposals for changes detailed in the Agenda attachment that include design, construction administration, and DSA coordination.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms. 
	 
Original Contract Amount                   $    226,750
Previous Change Order(s)                  $               0
Revision #001                                     $      50,000
	 
Revised Contract Amount                   $    276,750
	 
As a consulting contract this change is not restricted by Public Contract Code limitations to construction contracts.  The total architectural contract value with this revision #001 is 22% of the project’s construction value.  This is considered reasonable for a landscape renovation and retrofit project of this nature.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) #02 Revision #001 in the amount of $50,000 to Bellinger Foster Steinmetz Landscape Architects for the Central Green Project at Evergreen Valley College.

The San Jose City College currently does not have the required security cameras installed and emergency call stations implemented for a more secure campus.  Multiple facilities throughout the campus lack the manpower of campus security to prevent crime such as vandalism or theft. Therefore, San Jose City College requested that 20 locations throughout the campus be installed with new surveillance systems, ethernet cabling, and emergency call systems to increase security.
	 
In March 2013, the District approved an Independent Contract Agreement with Catalyst Consulting Group, Inc. to provide design and construction phase administration services for the project.  Since March 2013, Catalyst has worked to establish the Collegeâs needs, and refine the project design.  The College is pleased with the outcome of the design, and is looking forward to the planned move.
	 
A public bidding process for contractors was conducted between March 18, 2014 and March 26, 2014.  The project was advertised in local papers on March 7th, March 13th and published at 17 local builders exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to over 24 contractors.  A mandatory pre-bid meeting was held on March 18, 2014 with approximately nine interested contractors.  Bids were received from two bidders at 3:00 pm on March 27, 2014. 
	 
Netronix Integration Inc.                                            $ 79,006.86
Electronic Innovations, Inc.                                       $ 70,476.00
	 
Based on the evaluation of bid prices and required documentation, it was determined that Electronic Innovations Inc. was the apparent lowest responsible bidder.
	 
Electronic Innovations' bid was subsequently qualified in the amount of $70,476, and they were determined to be the successful bidder.

As part of State-funded Proposition 39, the California Community Colleges Chancellor's Office has provided San Jose Evergreen Valley Community College District with $485,588 in funding for energy efficiency projects for fiscal year 2013/2014. After reviewing several options for utilizing the State funding, the District has elected to replace existing metal-halide parking lot light fixtures with more energy efficient LED light fixtures at both campuses.  The project consists of replacing approximately 266 light fixtures at EVC and 136 fixtures at SJCC as part of the base contract bid. Additive alternate bid costs for replacement of street light fixtures were solicited from contractors bidding the base contract as part of the public bid process.  Bond funds will be used to pay for these additional fixtures.   
	 
On March 27, 2014, bids were received for the project. The bid package was posted on the District’s purchasing website, advertised in local papers and published at 20 local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to over 100 contractors including small and disadvantaged businesses.  The bid results are as follows:
	 
Intermountain Electric Co.                  Base $574,800            Additive Alternates $124,100  
General Lighting Service, Inc.            Base $845,880            Additive Alternates $180,000 
Tennyson Electric, Inc.                       Base $2,192,220         Additive Alternates $564,700 
	 
Based on the evaluation of the bids received, Intermountain Electric Company, a Small Business Enterprise from San Carlos, CA is determined to be the lowest responsible bidder in the amount of $698,900 (with all alternates).

On February 7, 2014, EVC’s President Yong and SJCC's Interim President Breland received a letter from the Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges (ACCJC) regarding the actions of the Commission at its meetings of January 8-10, 2014.   The Commission based its actions on their review of the colleges Midterm Reports and affirmed accreditation for both colleges.  The letter, nevertheless, requested that a follow up report be submitted by March 31, 2014, to address specific compliance with Standard III.A.1c that reads as follows:
	 
“Faculty and others directly responsible for student progress toward achieving stated student learning outcomes have, as a component of their evaluation, effectiveness in producing those learning outcomes.”
	 
Leadership from both colleges and the District Office met to discuss the letter and identify the necessary steps to comply with the Commission’s request.  In addition, a team from both colleges, including Presidents Yong and Breland and Vice Presidents Aytch and Graham, met with Commission staff to ensure clear understanding of the type of evidence and documentation necessary to satisfy the requirements.   This item includes two types of documents that meet the standard; the first, addresses faculty and the second, includes “others directly responsible for student progress (i.e. academic administrators)" as follows:
	 
Faculty - An agreement for a three year pilot program between FA, AFT 61567 (Union) and the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District (District) regarding the inclusion of Student Learning Outcomes (SLO’s) as a component of faculty evaluations.  The three year pilot program is an interim measure designed for the limited purposes of addressing the ACCJC’s requirements until the issues addressed in the pilot program are negotiated between the District and the Union.
	 
2. Academic Administrators - Board Approval of Consent Agenda  Item F-7 of April 8, 2014 – “Revisions to Academic Administrator Job Descriptions and Performance Appraisal Form to Address Responsibility for the Systematic Assessment of Student Progress and Learning Outcomes” and the proposed evaluation form.  The positions included in this process include  the following:

Dean of Language Arts.

Pursuant to the CCCT Board Governing Policies, the election of members of the CCCT board of the League will take place between March 10 and April 25. This year there are seven, three-year vacancies on the board and one one-year vacancy.
		 
Each member community college district board of the League shall have one vote for each of the eight vacancies on the CCCT board. Only one vote may be cast for any nominee or write-in candidate. The seven candidates who receive the most votes will serve three-year terms and the eighth top vote getter will complete the term that was vacated by a CCCT member that did not seek re-election in her district last November. In the event of a tie vote for the last position to be filled, the CCCT board will vote to break the tie.
		 
The fourteen trustees who have been nominated for election to the board are listed on the attached document sheet in the Secretary of State's random drawing order. An official ballot for the election is also attached, which will record the eight candidates chosen by the Board of Trustees at the meeting.  The ballot will then be signed by the Board President and Board Secretary and mailed to the CCCT Elections Committee.

The San Jose Evergreen Community College District is a member district in two Joint Powers Authority (JPA) organizations that have the purpose of providing insurance coverage for the district.  These JPAs are governed by a board of directors, with one director representing each district as appointed by each member districts' Board of Trustees.
	 
The Northern California Community College Pool (NCCCP) JPA is comprised of area community colleges and provides workers' compensation insurance to the member districts.  The Bay Area Community College Districts (BACCD) JPA provides property and liability insurance coverage.  Both programs have layered insurance structures to spread risk and provide maximum coverage for reasonable insurance rates.
	 
Board members are appointed by office to allow for changes in the those holding office.  Currently the board member for both JPAs is the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services and the alternate member for both JPAs is the Director of Fiscal Services.  The recommendation is to switch the appointments so that the board member for both JPAs is the Director of Fiscal Services and the alternative member for both JPAs is the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the resolution designating the Director of Fiscal Services as the District's representative and the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services as the alternate representative to the boards of the Northern California Community College Pool JPA and the Bay Area Community College Districts JPA.

items.item_details:
Each year community colleges project negative cash flows in some months and must engage in temporary borrowing in order to ensure that unrestricted funds are available to meet payroll and other operational expenses.  For many years the California Community College League has coordinated an effort to pool the cash needs of these districts by issuing one debt instrument for all districts.  This provides substantial savings in the cost of going to market with short-term debt instruments.  The cost of the Tax and Revenue Anticipation Note to the District is estimated to be approximately $25,000; however will be partially offset by the short-term investment earnings that the District will realize while the cash is deposited in the County's investment pool.
	 
The Fiscal Services Department has completed an initial projection of the District's restricted and unrestricted general funds for Fiscal Year 2014-2015.  It is anticipated that the District will experience a negative unrestricted cash balance during the second quarter of Fiscal Year 2014-2015.  Adoption of this resolution will mitigate the deficit unrestricted cash balance and provide a prudent cash balance throughout Fiscal Year 2014-2015.
	 
For reference, the District borrowed $15,000,000 in Fiscal Year 2011-2012; $10,000,000 in Fiscal Year 2012-2013; and $7,000,000 in Fiscal Year 2013-2014.  If this trend continues, it is possible that FY 2014-2015 will be the last year in the foreseeable future that the District will need to engage in temporary borrowing.
	 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt the attached resolution in order for the District to participate in the pooled TRANs program.  The initial projection of the District's restricted and unrestricted cash flow for Fiscal Year 2014-2015 is attached separately.

In recent Board meetings information has been presented to the Board regarding the location of the Roble and Acacia buildings at Evergreen Valley College within a State-designated no-build seismic zone.
	 
The District has taken actions to investigate, evaluate and determine the steps necessary to address this situation.  These included:
Engineering study of building safety
Preparation of cost estimates to address replacement or relocation of affected buildings
Notify the State and apply for funding 
Board notification
Analysis of options to repair, reconstruct or replace
	 
At the conclusion, with all considerations made, it was the consensus of the College and the Presidentâs recommendation that Roble and Acacia remain in service without modification during the construction of replacement buildings and pursuit of State funding for additional replacement project(s).  The Board concurred with this recommendation and approved such direction at its March 11, 2014 meeting.  Counsel has advised that the Board adopt the proposed resolution in order to maximize protection of the District and the Board to legal action under Education Code section 81177.

At the March 11, 2014, Governing Board Meeting, President Lease distributed notes of the Board Governance Task Force meeting of March 4, 2014, in which the task force, comprised of Trustees Lease, Ho and Cruz met with Chancellor Cepeda, Executive Administrative Assistant Joy Pace and Mr. Randy Parent, legal council representative from Liebert Cassidy and Whitmore, to review and revise the draft Board Governance Policies document. Consensus was reached in several areas including goals clarification, legal liabilities and compliance, differentiation between principles and policies, recommended format and next steps. The goal clarification was determined to develop and implement a governance policy model that ensures the effective and efficient participation of Trustees, including a clear understanding of roles and responsibilities among Trustees; differentiation of role and function between Trustees and the Chancellor and the commitment to ongoing evaluation of board performance and Chancellor accountability. Mr. Randy Parent proposed that the Board establish a set of Principles (developed by the Board), followed by the Policies Manual (developed for Board approval by the Chancellor through participatory governance) and followed by an Administrative Procedures Manual (developed by staff). Therefore, it is suggested that the current language derived from the Carver Policy Governance Model should be reclassified as Principles, i.e. a higher order of value that applies to the Board members in the performance of their work. In addition, Board Policies should remain as they are in Chapters I through VII (BP 1100 to BP 7700). The Board Governance Task Force also recommended the development of a document that includes the Board Mission, Vision and Values Statements, Board Ends Policies, Strategic Priorities for 2013-2017, Board Governance Principles and Administrative Procedures. The next steps will include a revision of the governance model adoption calendar, creation of the framework for the new agenda format and the establishment of an implementation date.  
	 
The task force met once again with Mr. Randy Parent on March 31, 2014, to review his draft of the document that was revised using the criteria reported to the board at the March 11 meeting. This draft document is being submitted to the Board for a first reading and will be submitted for approval at the April 22, 2014, Governing Board Meeting.

In order to keep pace with workforce demands, President Obama recently called for more Americans to get a year or more of college and stressed the significance of postsecondary certificates and workforce training efforts at community colleges, signaling the undeniably important function of Career & Technical Education (CTE) programs.  CTE is a vital piece of the national college completion agenda, yet historically it has not received much attention.  With a large share of projected job openings offering family-supporting wages requiring some college but less than a bachelor's degree, college CTE programs can make a tremendous  contribution toward the creation of a competitive national workforce and help recharge the local economy.
	 
To answer this federal call-to-action, community colleges are tailoring their offerings to address current labor market needs and designing programs to be accessible and valuable to students with different levels of preparation and at different stages of their careers. Recent high school graduates, under-employed and unemployed adults, incumbent workers looking for career advancement, and college graduates seeking retraining are all benefiting from reinvigorated CTE programs that offer clear pathways from shorter-term, entry-level to longer term, industry validated credentials in their chosen fields.  On the state level, industry-aligned CTE programs are helping California meet completion goals, reach workforce goals, meet equity goals, and realize the benefits of high school reform efforts.
	 
The goal of this presentation is to review new, external information recently available at the national, state, and local level that are major drivers for Career & Technical Education efforts occurring at San Jose City College.  The presentation may inform future policy decisions needed to follow step with community colleges around the state, reinvigorating CTE and workforce development programs and ensuring their relevance to local industry and to students.  A brief overview of San Jose City College’s self-evaluation of their CTE and workforce development preparedness will also be presented. 
 
The San Jose/Evergreen Community College District has also been invited to participate on the advisory board for the City of San Jose Silicon Valley Manufacturing Initiative in its effort to seek federal designation as a “Manufacturing Community” as will be presented by Chris Burton, Business Development Manager for the City of San Jose Office of Economic Development.
 
Neil Struthers, Business Development Officer for the National Electrical Contractors Association will present on his efforts to provide apprenticeship opportunities for SJCC students and to create clearly defined career pathways into construction and related industries.

Pursuant to Government Code Section 3547, the San Jose/Evergreen Community College District presents their re-opener proposal with the California School Employees Association, Chapter 363 for 2013-2014.  The San Jose/Evergreen Community College District will present the following Articles to be negotiated for 2013-2014.
	 
Article 3 - Released Time - Accounting for and recording use of time
	 
Article 8 - Work Schedules - address adjustments to assigned time and/or work schedules
	 
Article 13 - Leaves - non -paid provisions when all leaves are exhausted and/or leave not authorized 
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Present District's contract re-opener proposal for 2013-2014, and announcement of a public hearing to be conducted at the April 22, 2014 Board meeting.

items.item_details:
On March 11, 2014, the Board of Trustees authorized the District to sell Series C of general obligation bonds associated with Measure G 2004, to sell Series C general obligation bonds associated with Measure G 2010, and to refund (refinance) previously issued general obligation bonds to provide savings to the taxpayers within the District.  In anticipation of the sale the Chancellor, the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services, the Director of Fiscal Services, and Ms. Ann Kennedy provided a rating presentation to Standard & Poor's Rating Services and to Moody's Investor Services on March 4, 2014.
	 
On March 19, 2014, Moody's Investors Service reaffirmed the District credit rating of Aa1, and removed the "negative outlook" that was given to the District in 2012.  The strengths driving the rating were the District's stable and large assessed valuation, the District's diverse local economy, and the District's basic aid designation.
	 
On March 25, 2014, the District received its credit rating of AA from Standard and Poor's Rating Services, which is up from the previous rating of AA- given to the District in 2012.  The rationale was based upon the District's location in the heart of Silicon Valley and access to a broad and diverse area economy anchored by a strong technology presence; the District's maintenance of strong reserves; the inherent operational flexibility of community colleges given their ability to control class sections and curriculum offerings, an operational feature not shared by K-12 districts; and the District's moderate overall debt burden.
	 
Also attached to this item is a listing of credit ratings amongst other California Community Colleges for the Board of Trustees to compare and contrast.
